description: A late innovation, apparently by analogy with sit → sat; spit → spat, etc. First recorded in the eighteenth century.

entries.meaning: simple past tense and past participle of shit
examples: Hey Schlossie [=Jeremy Schloss], I just shat in your shoe.

description: Arabic شَطّ‎ (šaṭṭ); see chott; for the spelling, compare Shatt al-Arab.

examples: All this region round the shats has been called the “Jerid” from the time of the Arab occupation.

description: Sometimes said to be a shortening of an obsolete word (*)shattle (“needle”), but more likely a shortening of the synonymous (pine) shatter.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Maryland, Delaware) Synonym of shatter (“a pine needle”).
examples: Dryden used the car that afternoon to get shats for the hog pen of Ollie Hitchens, who [...] gave Dryden a dollar for his services in getting the shats [...] some pine shats for his father.
